history.content: When I took the course I found that generally there were multiple parts, and while some parts relied on others, it was always possible to work on at least 2 things simultaneously for a little bit, pausing when you needed to wait for the other side to be done. We kind of pair programmed it, splitting into pairs working on tasks. For some things that were really simple, like some of the easier syscalls, one person would just take it themselves. You'll spend a good amount of time as a group of 4 discussing your design for your design document, and that'll help make it a little more clear on what tasks can kind of be separated. Also, we found it helpful to physically meet with the whole team, even if we were going to split into 2s. This way we could pull people to discuss a flaw in the design we chose or to have a fresh set of eyes on things. You'll find out pretty quickly what works best for you and your group.

Hey! For those of you who have already taken 162, what are some tips you have about splitting up the work for projects? Pair programming is doable with 2 people, but how do you suggest working with 4 people...I can't imagine working on 1 part with 4 people at the same time, do we just code on 1 computer or split up, which will probably cause merge conflicts lol? I have read elsewhere that splitting up the work by parts of the project doesn't work because many of the parts rely on previous ones, so things can break, is this the common consensus? Any advice on how to approach the projects, splitting up the work, how often to meet with your team, and/or timing would be much appreciated!
history.subject: CS162 Projects Advice
